page.title: 02Ecology
page.content: The LINDEAN block lies between 100 and 300 metres above Ordnance Datum on Silurian Age sedimentary rocks and contains both hard and soft strata with acid-neutral shales and greywackes and some more limey fine shale bands. The landscape has changed greatly since the Mesolithic settlers had their flint "factory" above the Tweed at Rink: the native forest has entirely gone, its demise hastened by the use - since medieval times - of the valleys as sheep-pastures. Nevertheless some herb-rich stands occur on river terraces and streamsides. The 350-400 flowering plants grasses and ferns support a wide range of insects and the usual range of mammals and birds. The numbers of water voles and otters are declining. Badgers are unvarying.
